excerpt: New Zealand's only 'castle', this Scottish baronial-style grand estate is open for tours.
detail_description: Larnach Castle, the only 'castle' in New Zealand, is a Scottish baronial-style estate that offers tours to visitors. The castle boasts impressive craftsmanship and materials, with well-maintained gardens that follow an Alice in Wonderland-esque theme. The vibrant flowers during springtime are a sight to behold and have been meticulously cultivated over 45 years. Visitors can leisurely wander through the gardens or simply bask in the sunshine.
name: Larnach Castle
address: 145 Camp Road, Larnachs Castle, Dunedin 9077, New Zealand

excerpt: Exhibits on natural history along with a hands-on science area, planetarium & butterfly house.
detail_description: Tūhura Otago Museum in Dunedin, New Zealand offers a diverse range of cultural and natural history exhibits. Visitors can explore hands-on science areas, a planetarium, and a butterfly house. The museum is home to rare collections of natural specimens and human artifacts from various Pacific cultures. Permanent exhibitions include Tangata Whenua showcasing Southern Maori artifacts, as well as a maritime gallery featuring a massive Fin Whale skeleton and ship models.
name: Tūhura Otago Museum
address: 419 Great King Street, Dunedin North, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Museum exploring history of local settlement, with kid-friendly exhibits & events, plus a cafe.
detail_description: Toitu Otago Settlers Museum in Dunedin offers a fascinating exploration of the local settlement history, with exhibits and events suitable for all ages. The museum showcases the experiences of early Scottish settlers like John McGlashan, who sought to recreate the charm of Edinburgh in New Zealand. Visitors can learn about their endeavors and enjoy kid-friendly displays as well as a cafe on-site.
name: Toitu Otago Settlers Museum
address: 31 Queens Gardens, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: A historic hand-carved tunnel leads to to this popular diving & snorkeling spot with cliffs & caves.
detail_description: Tunnel Beach in Dunedin, located on the Otago coastline, is a popular spot for diving and snorkeling. It was once privately owned by the influential Cargill family and features wind-battered arches, sandstone cliffs, and headlands. The beach is accessed through a hand-carved tunnel that leads to a secluded area where the Cargill daughters used to sunbathe and swim.
name: Tunnel Beach
address: Otago Region 9076, New Zealand

excerpt: Iconic 1906 building famed for its Flemish Renaissance architecture, mosaic floors & stained glass.
detail_description: Dunedin Railway Station, completed in 1906, is a renowned landmark in the city. This iconic building showcases Flemish Renaissance architecture and is famous for its mosaic floors and stained glass windows. It serves as a central hub for various train routes including the Taieri Gorge Railway, Coastal Pacific train, and TranzAlpine train route. The station's grandeur reflects the city's pride as the Otago rail network's hub.
name: Dunedin Railway Station
address: 3074332, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Serene gardens with walking paths amid 6,000+ plant species, as well as a cafe & an aviary.
detail_description: Dunedin Botanic Garden, established in 1863 as the first of its kind in New Zealand, spans 28 hectares and is home to over 6,800 plant species. The lower gardens boast an Edwardian Winter Garden glasshouse with tropical plants and a serene Japanese Garden with a bamboo grove. Even during winter, the garden offers beautiful sights such as the flowering Himalayan daphne and a dedicated section for winter and spring flowers.
name: Dunedin Botanic Garden
address: Cnr &, Great King Street North, Dunedin North, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Large wildlife sanctuary offering an observatory, exhibits, guided tours & a cafe on scenic grounds.
detail_description: The Royal Albatross Centre is a large wildlife sanctuary located on the scenic Otago Peninsula in Dunedin. It offers an observatory, exhibits, guided tours, and a cafe for visitors to enjoy. The center is the only one of its kind in the world and provides opportunities for visitors to get up close and personal with the Royal Albatross. Activities include hand-rearing chicks, learning about conservation efforts, and going on guided tours of the peninsula to discover its history and wildlife.
name: Royal Albatross Centre
address: 1259 Harington Point Road, Harington Point 9077, New Zealand

excerpt: Grand, well-preserved former merchant home dating to the early 1900s, offering guided tours.
detail_description: Olveston Historic Home, located on Royal Terrace in Dunedin, is a well-preserved former merchant home dating back to the early 1900s. The house offers guided tours and serves as a walk-in time capsule, providing visitors with a glimpse into New Zealand's European-influenced history during that era. Built by local philanthropist David Theomin, the house features a striking facade designed by English architect Sir George Ernest.
name: Olveston Historic Home
address: 42 Royal Terrace, Dunedin North, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Classic Chinese garden with features such as a lake & grand archway, plus an audio tour & tea house.
detail_description: Lan Yuan, Dunedin Chinese Garden is a classic representation of a traditional Chinese landscape painting. It was created to honor the city's Chinese heritage and its sister city relationship with Shanghai. The garden features a picturesque lake, a grand archway, and ever-changing seasonal vistas that offer unexpected corners to explore. Visitors can enjoy an audio tour, relax in the tea house, bring a picnic, or engage in puzzles and games while soaking up the tranquility of this authentic Southern Hemisphere gem.
name: Lan Yuan, Dunedin Chinese Garden
address: 39 Queens Gardens, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: When visiting Dunedin, don't miss the chance to explore Baldwin St, known as the world's steepest street. While in the area, you can also marvel at natural attractions like the Pyramids at Okia Reserve and Tunnel Beach. The latter boasts a stunning sandstone sea arch extending into the Pacific Ocean and a hand-carved tunnel that leads to a tranquil beach.
name: Baldwin St
address: North East Valley, Dunedin 9010, New Zealand

excerpt: Scenic waterfront & mountain setting offering views of penguins, sea lions & other wildlife.
detail_description: Otago Peninsula, located south of Dunedin, offers a stunning waterfront and mountain backdrop where visitors can enjoy breathtaking views of penguins, sea lions, and other wildlife. A tour of the area includes sightseeing in Dunedin city, a guided tour of Larnach Castle and its grounds on the peninsula, as well as visits to attractions like Dunedin's Chinese Garden and the Otago Early Settlers Museum.
name: Otago Peninsula
address: Otago Region 9077, New Zealand

excerpt: Landmark red-brick 1876 brewery offering guided tours & tastings, with an ale house & gift shop.
detail_description: Speight's Brewery, a historic red-brick brewery established in 1876, is a must-visit landmark offering guided tours and tastings. The brewery features a working still and also houses the NZ Whisky Co, continuing the tradition of whisky production in Dunedin. Visitors can explore the Speights Heritage Centre for an informative tour through the brewery and museum, followed by tasting sessions at the private Heritage Bar.
name: Speight's Brewery
address: 200 Rattray Street, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Source for New Zealand art from 1860 to present, European works & events like lectures & screenings.
detail_description: The Dunedin Public Art Gallery is a significant source for New Zealand art, showcasing works from 1860 to the present as well as European pieces. It is known for featuring pioneering NZ artists like Ralph Hotere. Visitors can also explore the Hocken Collections and Gallery at the University of Otago, as well as the unique bone-based art of Bruce Mahalski at the Dunedin Museum of Natural Mystery.
name: Dunedin Public Art Gallery
address: 30 Octagon, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Sandy beach known for surfing breaks & backed by a promenade lined with seafood restaurants & bars.
detail_description: Saint Clair Beach is a popular destination in Dunedin, known for its sandy shores and excellent surfing opportunities. The beach is backed by a lively promenade featuring seafood restaurants and bars. It is the closest beach to the city and is often frequented by various wildlife such as seals, penguins, sea lions, and occasionally sharks. Visitors can enjoy walking along the dunes or strolling along John Wilson Drive while taking in the stunning views.
name: Saint Clair Beach
address: St Clair, Dunedin 9012, New Zealand

detail_description: Embark on an unforgettable journey through the stunning landscapes of New Zealand with a ride on the renowned Taieri Gorge Railway in Dunedin. This popular tourist attraction offers a scenic adventure through lush green valleys and majestic mountains. The beautifully restored carriages feature large viewing windows, air conditioning, well-maintained toilets, and a snack bar offering refreshments. Knowledgeable guides provide engaging commentary throughout the 5.5-hour tour, ensuring a delightful experience for all passengers.
name: Taieri Gorge Railway
address: Dunedin Railway Station Anzac Square, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9054, New Zealand

detail_description: Dunedin, known as the Edinburgh of the South, boasts impressive Scottish-influenced architecture and Victorian and Edwardian buildings. Visitors can explore iconic sites like Dunedin Railway Station, First Church of Otago, and Larnach Castle's gardens for free. Baldwin Street's steep gradient offers a unique experience, while foodies can enjoy a Saturday farmers market at the railway station and sample haggis at Leckie's butcher.
name: Dunedin Street Art Trail
address: 76 Vogel Street, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Farmers market open Saturdays with vendors selling local meats, produce, artisanal goods & snacks.
detail_description: Every Saturday morning, the Otago Farmers Market comes alive with a vibrant community atmosphere and a wide array of local products. Located near the ornate Dunedin Railway Station, this market is exclusively dedicated to vendors from the Otago region. Visitors can explore an assortment of offerings including local meats, produce, artisanal goods, snacks, peanut butter, microgreens, fruits and vegetables, organic coffees, olive oils, hummus and falafel.
name: Otago Farmers Market, Every Saturday Morning
address: 36 Anzac Avenue, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Wildlife sanctuary with native animals such as kiwi, plus walking tracks, a visitor centre & a cafe.
detail_description: Orokonui Ecosanctuary - Te Korowai o Mihiwaka is a wildlife sanctuary located just 20 kilometers north of Dunedin. Spanning 307 hectares in the Orokonui Valley, it is home to native animals like kiwi and Takahe, as well as a variety of endangered species. The sanctuary is surrounded by an 8.7-km predator-proof fence, allowing native flora and fauna to thrive without the threat of non-native pests.
name: Orokonui Ecosanctuary
address: 600 Blueskin Road, Dunedin 9081, New Zealand

excerpt: Dunedin is a city in New Zealand, at the head of Otago Harbour on the South Island’s southeast coast. It's known for its Scottish and Maori heritage, Victorian and Edwardian architecture, and a large student population. Hiking and cycling trails crisscross the dramatic landscape of the adjoining Otago Peninsula, home to colonies of albatross, sea lions and rare yellow-eyed penguins.
detail_description: Dunedin, a city in New Zealand, is situated at the head of Otago Harbour on the South Island’s southeast coast. The city boasts a rich heritage blending Scottish and Maori influences, evident in its Victorian and Edwardian architecture. Additionally, it is home to a vibrant student population.
name: Dunedin
address: New Zealand

excerpt: Scenic, wind-swept landscape at the end of the Otago Peninsula & home to over 10,000 seabirds.
detail_description: Taiaroa Head, located at the end of the Otago Peninsula, offers a scenic and wind-swept landscape that is home to over 10,000 seabirds. Visitors can enjoy captivating experiences such as witnessing albatrosses soaring above the headland and marveling at stunning butterflies at Discovery World.
name: Taiaroa Head
address: Otago Region 9077, New Zealand

detail_description: Pineapple Track Walkway in Dunedin offers breathtaking panoramic views of the city, Otago Harbour, and even the Southern Alps on a clear day. The track is a short but steep hike from Flagstaff / Whares Flat Road and leads down to the city. It was named after a local grocer who used to guide people up the track and offer tinned pineapple as a snack at the top.
name: Pineapple Track Walkway
address: Booth Road, Glenleith, Dunedin 9010, New Zealand

detail_description: Signal Hill Road offers a must-do experience with its stunning views over Otago Harbour and the city. The walk up to Signal Hill, standing at 393 meters, provides far-reaching panoramas that stretch across Dunedin. At the summit, visitors can admire the monument commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Treaty of Waitangi in 1940, which is New Zealand's founding document.
name: Signal Hill Road
address: Opoho, Dunedin 9010, New Zealand

detail_description: "The Octagon" is a stunning architectural marvel located in the heart of the city. This iconic building offers a unique and immersive experience for visitors, with its eight-sided design and modern interior. The structure houses a variety of shops, restaurants, and entertainment options, making it a popular destination for both locals and tourists. Visitors can explore the diverse range of offerings within "The Octagon," from upscale boutiques to cozy cafes, all while taking in the striking design elements that make this building so distinctive.
name: The Octagon
address: Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Largest of 5 campuses comprising the country's oldest university, including its School of Business.
detail_description: The University of Otago is the largest of five campuses in New Zealand's oldest university. It includes the School of Business and offers fellowship and residency schemes for collaboration and public programming with the gallery. The campus features impressive Neo-Gothic and neo-Classical buildings, showcasing Dunedin's wealth and ambition. Additionally, Dunedin, home to the university, boasts a rich Scottish heritage and offers unique attractions like the Chingford Park Disc Golf Course.
name: University of Otago
address: 362 Leith Street, Dunedin North, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: The New Zealand Sports Hall of Fame, located in Dunedin at the impressive Dunedin Railway Station, is a captivating museum that celebrates the country's rich sporting history. It showcases the achievements of 75 of New Zealand's greatest sports figures through memorabilia, trophies, and tools of their trades. The collection includes stories and contributions from inducted sportsmen and women across various sports. Visitors can explore exhibits featuring legendary athletes and their remarkable accomplishments.
name: New Zealand Sports Hall of Fame
address: Railway Station Anzac Avenue, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Guided tours of a preserved gasworks featuring a working boiler house, fitting shop & steam engines.
detail_description: The Dunedin Gasworks Museum is a captivating destination for history and industrial machinery enthusiasts. It offers guided tours through a preserved gasworks, featuring a working boiler house, fitting shop, and steam engines. The museum provides insight into the evolution of gas production over the years and showcases live shows that highlight its historical significance.
name: Dunedin Gasworks Museum
address: 20 Braemar Street, South Dunedin, Dunedin 9012, New Zealand

excerpt: Port Chalmers is a town serving as the main port of the city of Dunedin, New Zealand. Port Chalmers lies ten kilometres inside Otago Harbour, some 15 kilometres northeast of Dunedin's city centre. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Port Chalmers, located in New Zealand, serves as the primary port for Dunedin. Situated ten kilometers inside Otago Harbour and about 15 kilometers northeast of Dunedin's city center, it offers picturesque viewpoints such as Island Terrace and the road above town. These spots provide stunning views of Quarantine Island/Goat Island and the Otago Peninsula.
name: Port Chalmers
address: Dunedin, New Zealand

excerpt: Volcanic outcrop with sweeping coastal views & summit access by rough road or forested trail.
detail_description: Mount Cargill is a volcanic outcrop in Dunedin, offering sweeping coastal views and summit access via rough roads or forested trails. The rainwater harvested from Mount Cargill is used to make spirits at a local distillery, reflecting the area's terroir. Botanicals are sourced locally, and waste products are utilized creatively. Visitors can drive or hike to the top of Mount Cargill, with the latter option providing unique sights such as the Organ Pipes.
name: Mount Cargill
address: 9085, New Zealand

detail_description: Natures Wonders, located at the end of the Peninsula, is a working sheep farm run by the Reid Family. They offer Argo tours of Taiaroa Head and the farm, as well as catamaran tours exploring Otago Harbour and Tairoa Head Lighthouse. The coastal sheep farm boasts stunning beaches that remain untouched by humans, providing a habitat for yellow-eyed penguins and New Zealand fur seals. Visitors can observe these animals in their natural environment throughout the year.
name: Natures Wonders
address: 1265 Harington Point Road, Taiaroa Head, Harington Point 9077, New Zealand

detail_description: The Dunedin Museum of Natural Mystery, located in a downtown villa on Royal Terrace, showcases the eclectic and fascinating collections of local artist Bruce Mahalski. The museum features an array of artifacts including skulls, bones, fossils, biological curiosities, ethnological art, bone sculptures, animal paintings created by Mahalski himself and other intriguing objects.
name: The Dunedin Museum of Natural Mystery
address: 61 Royal Terrace, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: Victory Beach, located on the Otago Peninsula, boasts 3.5 kilometers of coastline, making it the longest beach in the area. The surrounding grasslands offer a picturesque backdrop to the expansive ocean views. A well-maintained track from the car park leads to The Pyramids, a geological wonder featuring basalt volcanic columns with symmetrical shapes. Visitors can also explore the Little Pyramid with its walking track offering panoramic views of Okia reserve, wetlands, dunes and ocean.
name: Victory Beach
address: Okia Flat 9077, New Zealand

detail_description: Sandfly Bay, located on the Otago Peninsula just 15 kilometers east of central Dunedin, is a stunning coastal destination known for its prominent sand dunes and windswept shores. Despite its name, which reflects the windy nature of its sandy shores rather than the presence of sandflies, this bay offers beautiful vistas and a chance to observe wildlife such as yellow-eyed penguins and sea lions in their natural habitat.
name: Sandfly Bay Wildlife Refuge
address: Sandfly Bay, Otago Region 9077, New Zealand

detail_description: When visiting the Otago Peninsula in Dunedin, make sure to include the Blue Penguins Pukekura Experience Tour in your itinerary. This tour offers a unique opportunity to witness little blue penguins waddling onto shore at Pilots Beach as the sun sets. The experience begins at the Royal Albatross Centre, where you can explore exhibitions before being introduced to the penguins and heading to a viewing platform to watch them return to their colony.
name: Blue Penguins Pukekura
address: 1245 Harington Point Road, Harington Point 9077, New Zealand

detail_description: The Organ Pipes in Dunedin are a remarkable collection of basalt pillars formed by volcanic activity millions of years ago. Similar to the Giants Causeway in Northern Ireland, these interlocking stone columns offer stunning mountain-top views. Visitors can take a short walk to reach a platform with views of the Organ Pipes and explore the surrounding area for an outdoor adventure. The site is complemented by the dramatic Sutton Salt Lake and nearby Orokonui Ecosanctuary, where native flora and fauna thrive.
name: The Organ Pipes
address: Otago Region, New Zealand

detail_description: City walks is a tour operator with a focus on heritage buildings and architecture in the city of Dunedin. The company offers self-guided tours of various parts of the city, as well as group tours. Highly knowledgeable tour guides provide interesting and engaging commentary on the history and features of the sites visited.
name: City Walks
address: 50 The Octagon, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: Brighton Beach in Dunedin offers a variety of attractions for visitors. The beach features multiple viewpoints that provide stunning vistas of the expansive shoreline and rock formations, making it a paradise for photographers. Families can enjoy the beach's diverse offerings, including surfing opportunities on one side and a tranquil estuary with rock pools on the other. Children can play in the shallow river area, while adults can take leisurely walks along the shore or relax with a hot cup of coffee.
name: Brighton Beach
address: Otago Region 9035, New Zealand

excerpt: Neo-Gothic Anglican church, consecrated in 1919, with stained-glass windows & a large pipe organ.
detail_description: St Paul's Cathedral, a neo-Gothic Anglican church consecrated in 1919, is situated at the heart of Dunedin's main city plaza. Designed by Sedding and Wheatley, it replaced the former Parish of Saint Paul due to its poorly-devised construction. The cathedral is known for its stained-glass windows and large pipe organ. Although it ran out of funds before completion, it boasts massive foundations and a tremendous vaulted ceiling.
name: St Paul's Cathedral
address: 228 Stuart Street, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Operator of scenic train trips departing from an old station decorated in a highly ornamental style.
detail_description: Dunedin Railways offers scenic train trips departing from a beautifully ornate old station. The journey takes passengers through the stunning Otago hinterland, showcasing New Zealand's dramatic scenery and the country's early rail engineering marvels. The trip includes crossing the Taieri Gorge on a high viaduct, passing numerous high bridges and 10 tunnels carved out of hillsides.
name: Dunedin Railways
address: 22 Anzac Avenue, Dunedin, 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: Forsyth Barr Stadium, located in Dunedin, New Zealand, is a versatile and unique multi-purpose venue with a seating capacity of up to 30,000 people. It boasts world-class facilities such as a retractable roof, concert-quality sound system, and high-definition video screen. The stadium hosts various events including concerts featuring international acts like Ed Sheeran and Elton John as well as sports events like rugby matches for the local teams Highlanders and Otago provincial side.
name: Forsyth Barr Stadium
address: Anzac Avenue, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Massive Presbyterian church built in the 1800s in the gothic style with a soaring, gabled steeple.
detail_description: First Church of Otago is a grand Presbyterian church constructed in the 1800s, featuring gothic architecture and a towering steeple. Made of brick and adorned with Oamaru limestone, it boasts intricate stained glass windows honoring war casualties. The well-maintained grounds are adorned with benches, trees, flower beds, and lush lawns. Dunedin offers excellent opportunities for viewing the Southern Lights, with prime locations including Sandfly Bay and Hoopers Inlet.
name: First Church Of Otago
address: 415 Moray Place, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: Nestled at the southern end of St Clair Beach, the St Clair Hot Salt Water Pool is a beloved destination for both locals and visitors alike. This outdoor oasis boasts heated waters maintained at a comfortable 28 degrees, providing a perfect escape from Dunedin's chilly temperatures. Families will appreciate the dedicated paddling pool for toddlers and modern changing facilities, including options for those with disabilities.
name: St Clair Hot Salt Water Pool
address: Esplanade, St Clair, Dunedin 9012, New Zealand

detail_description: Emerson's Brewery, part of the Lion group, is a pioneering craft brewery known for its innovative beers and delicious brewery food. The modern HQ in Dunedin offers a buzzing space where visitors can enjoy daily tastings and explore the working brewery. The Taproom menu features an array of hot chips paired with their signature beers, including unique flavors like truffle oil and hop salt. Additionally, the seasonal Brewer's Reserve series showcases interesting variations of classic beer styles.
name: Emerson's Brewery
address: 70 Anzac Avenue, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt:
Portobello is a village beside the Otago Harbour halfway along the Otago Peninsula in Dunedin City, New Zealand. It lies at the foot of a small peninsula between Portobello Bay and Latham Bay.
Like scores of Dunedin features, Portobello was named after a locality in Edinburgh, Scotland, also called Portobello. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Portobello, located in Dunedin City, New Zealand, is a charming village nestled between Portobello Bay and Latham Bay. The name of the village was inspired by a locality in Edinburgh, Scotland. As you make your way towards Portobello along the 'low road,' you'll witness evidence of Dunedin's volcanic history.
name: Portobello
address: Dunedin, New Zealand

detail_description: Elm Wildlife Tours, situated in the wildlife capital of New Zealand, Dunedin, offers a wide range of tour options for nature enthusiasts. Visitors can embark on adventurous treks and hikes to witness the diverse biodiversity up close. The tours also extend beyond the region, providing multi-day international excursions with thrilling activities. The Otago Peninsula is home to charming sea-based wildlife such as penguins, sea lions, and royal albatrosses.
name: Elm Wildlife Tours
address: 20 Fryatt Street, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: Nestled along the stunning Otago Peninsula in New Zealand, Sandfly Bay is a true treasure for nature lovers and adventure seekers alike. This picturesque beach features striking coastal rock formations and serene waters that create a sense of seclusion. The expansive sand dunes invite visitors to explore walking trails or simply relax on the wide sandy shores, perfect for sunbathing, family games, or delightful picnics. Wildlife enthusiasts will be thrilled by the diverse native species that call Sandfly Bay home.
name: Sandfly Bay
address: Otago Region, New Zealand

detail_description: Signal Hill in Dunedin is a must-visit for breathtaking panoramic views of the city and its surroundings. Standing at 393 meters high, this lookout point offers an impressive bird's-eye view of Otago Harbour and the peninsula. Whether you hike the scenic trail through Logan Park or drive to the top, you'll be rewarded with stunning vistas of Dunedin's skyline and coastline. On clear days, you can even see Port Chalmers and the Southern Ocean.
name: Signal Hill
address: St Leonards, Dunedin 9022, New Zealand

detail_description: OCHO Chocolate Factory, short for Otago Chocolate Company, is a must-visit destination for chocolate enthusiasts. Located in Dunedin, New Zealand, this boutique factory offers unique tours and tastings where visitors can witness the craft of making award-winning chocolate from ethically sourced Pacific island cocoa beans. The factory produces around 10,000 bars per week and boasts a wide range of interesting flavors, from single origins to festival-themed chocolates.
name: OCHO Chocolate Factory
address: 10 Roberts Street, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: Boat tours to spot Southern Ocean wildlife like fur seals & penguins around the Otago Peninsula.
detail_description: Monarch Wildlife Cruises & Tours offers boat tours around the Otago Peninsula, providing an opportunity to spot Southern Ocean wildlife such as fur seals and penguins. The area is renowned for its eco-tourism, described by Dr. David Bellamy as the finest example in the world. With departures from Wellers Wharf, visitors can embark on a one-hour cruise to marvel at the wonders of this magnificent region.
name: Monarch Wildlife Cruises & Tours
address: 20 Fryatt Street, Central Dunedin, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

detail_description: No8 Distillery in Dunedin is a family-owned boutique distillery that has captured the hearts of locals and visitors alike. Their unique creations such as pineapple rum, limoncello, hibiscus gin, and absinthe showcase their passion for crafting exceptional spirits. The owners' deep-rooted connection to distilling is evident in the quality and variety of their offerings. Visitors praise the informative and personalized tasting experiences, highlighting the dedication and knowledge that goes into each product.
name: No8 Distillery
address: 90 Bond Street, DUNEDIN, Dunedin 9016, New Zealand

excerpt: St Clair is a coastal residential suburb of Dunedin, New Zealand. It is located on the Pacific Ocean coast five kilometres from the city centre on the southwesternmost part of the coastal plain which ... Wikipedia.
detail_description: St Clair is a charming residential area situated in Dunedin, New Zealand, just five kilometers from the city center along the picturesque Pacific Ocean coast. The suburb offers a tranquil ambiance with its leafy surroundings and proximity to the waterfront. One of its highlights is the Esplanade at St Clair, where visitors can indulge in an inviting atmosphere while savoring Italian comfort food and refreshing aperol spritz. The dining experience includes waterfront views accompanied by the soothing sounds of crashing waves and sea spray.
name: St Clair
address: Dunedin 9012, New Zealand
